traversed the nucleus just where the neck of the central cell touches
its margin, so that the circumambient cell is only on one side of it.
If on the other hand, the plane of division should happen not to
pass through the central cell at all, so as to traverse the circumambient
cell alone, a <u>single</u> single broad cavity will present itself in the vertical
section as shown in Plate VII, Fig 4. Frequently however, it happens,
as in the specimens represented in Plate II, Fig. 2, that the circumambient
segment is partially subdivided on one side by an interposed
partition; and then a vertical section will show <u>four</u> chambers
as is seen in Plate V, Fig 2, the central segment having a single portion
of the circumambient segment on one side of it, and a double portion
on the other. Some remarkable varieties in the size of the
nucleus, and in the mode of its connection with the surrounding
parts, will be <s>described</s> noticed hereafter (<s>Sect.</s> §§ 44-46, and 54,55)

16 In describing the structure of the <u>concentric zones</u> which
successively surround the nucleus, it will be convenient to
distinguish between the <u>simple</u> and <u>complex</u> types according to
which the Orbitolite disks may be generated; the former being
characterised by the existence of only one layer or 'floor' of segments,
